html: The way I have it set up, the binaries from the engine ends up in /usr/bin,  there is a measure of success there. Both vegastrike and vegasettings support a switch which tells them where the data directory is. The files from the Production-Assets ends up in /usr/share/vegastrike on my system, that is where I would expect game data to be. There are a few config files and icons and so that really don't belong in the game data directory..... Thing is, with a proper install target for make, one can set the install directory, and this is also a variable that can be passed to the binaries at build time, so they would know where to look for the data when it runs. The packagers have a neat trick where they fool the install target to install into a chroot, and so all the files of the game is captured, zipped and ready to install on similar systems. Easy-peasy. I know this part of developing is not that glamarous... so I'll have a crack at where each of the files should be, and feed it back to you guys for comments. From that, we can define an install target for make that makes everybody happy.

html: @Loki1950 if there is no development going to happen in Assets-Production, why have it as a git repo at all? The same purpose can be achieved by hosting a tarball pulled from master at a good time. It makes for a smaller (resumable) download, simpler packaging and provides a stable base to build the engine against. At the moment the vegastrike-git package in AUR uses the Assets-Production git repository, as that was what was what was suggested in the install instructions. Changing it over to Assets-Master is easy enough to do, but involves pulling a rather large git repo.

html:
first thing to note: when loading up the VS UtCS Deb it said I already had the same version installed - which would have been the 0.6.0 alpha 3 release...so seems we're missing the alphaN, betaN info from the release data.

Yes, we are missing the alphaN, betaN info from the release data. I tried including it, but it looks like the .deb versioning scheme requires versions more along the lines of 0.6.0-1alpha1. (No v in front, and a digit right after the dash.) So we would either need to have our Travis version numbers follow that convention, or do some sort of conversion within the CMake file.

What are your thoughts on that?
text:
> first thing to note: when loading up the VS UtCS Deb it said I already had the same version installed - which would have been the 0.6.0 alpha 3 release...so seems we're missing the `alphaN`, `betaN` info from the release data.

Yes, we are missing the `alphaN`, `betaN` info from the release data. I tried including it, but it looks like the .deb versioning scheme requires versions more along the lines of `0.6.0-1alpha1`. (No `v` in front, and a digit right after the dash.) So we would either need to have our Travis version numbers follow that convention, or do some sort of conversion within the CMake file.

What are your thoughts on that?

html: I'd make the conversion in the CMake file or a script as each package systems (DMG, Windows/MSI, DEB, RPM, etc) will have their own independent requirements. We should, however, define a specific format for our releases too which the the script can depend on, and we can then make easily parse-able
text: I'd make the conversion in the CMake file or a script as each package systems (DMG, Windows/MSI, DEB, RPM, etc) will have their own independent requirements. We should, however, define a specific format for our releases too which the the script can depend on, and we can then make easily parse-able

  • v0.7.0-alpha1 would become 0.7.0+alpha1
  • v0.7.0-beta1 would become 0.7.0+beta1
  • v0.7.0 would become 0.7.0

I think these versions would compare in the right order. Does this look right to you guys?

html:
if [ -f /etc/os-release ]
then
    export OS_RELEASE_LOCATION="/etc/os-release"
elif [ -f /usr/lib/os-release ]
then
    export OS_RELEASE_LOCATION="/usr/lib/os-release"
else
    echo "os-release file not found; unable to continue"
    exit 1
fi
export LINUX_ID=$(cat $OS_RELEASE_LOCATION | grep ^ID= | sed 's/^ID=//' | tr -d '"\n')
echo "LINUX_ID = ${LINUX_ID}"
export LINUX_CODENAME=$(cat $OS_RELEASE_LOCATION | grep ^VERSION_CODENAME= | sed 's/^VERSION_CODENAME=//' | tr -d '"\n')
echo "LINUX_CODENAME = ${LINUX_CODENAME}"
export LINUX_VERSION_ID=$(cat $OS_RELEASE_LOCATION | grep ^VERSION_ID= | sed 's/^VERSION_ID=//' | tr -d '"\n')
echo "LINUX_VERSION_ID = ${LINUX_VERSION_ID}"
